title: matt hancock refuses to apologise again
story: MATT Hancock has twice refused to apologise over huge PPE failures today - after he was confronted by the son of an NHS worker who died.This morning the Health Secretary was challenged by Intisar Chowdhury, the son of NHS doctor Abdul Mabud Chowdhury who died earlier this month.He urged Mr Hanock to admit his mistakes, and made a desperate plea for more PPE.And this afternoon reporters challenged him to apologise to families of loves ones who have died as the Government didnt protect them.Intisar told Nick Ferrari on LBC this morning: He wrote a request for more PPE to the Prime Minister... that was ignored, two weeks later he passed away, do you regret not taking my dads concerns, my -year-old sisters dads concerns... seriously At least  NHS staff and  social care workers have already died from coronavirus.Mr Hancock expressed his condolences to Intisar, but would not admit mistakes had been made.He said: Im really sorry about your dads death and Ive seen the comments youve made and I think its very brave of you to be speaking out in public.We took very, very seriously what your father said and weve been working around the clock to ensure theres enough protective equipment.Mr Hancock said they looked into each and every case of NHS and social care workers who had died to understand why it had happened and what needed to be improved.And this afternoon he told the No press conference: I think that is unreasonable as a question.From the start we knew there was a very signicant challenge with care homes.Enormous work gone on in Government to monitor this from the start.We are constantly learning from what happens and how we support people across the care sector.The health and social care services have been grappling with problems obtaining enough PPE since the start of the crisis.Despite the Government saying over one billion pieces of PPE have been delivered, there have been continual problems ensuring it gets to the hospitals that need it most.We are backing a proposal by Lord Ashcroft to honour our health heroes with the gallantry gong given for acts of bravery that did not take place in battle.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.According to the Royal College of Physicians, one in four doctors are still having to reuse single-use PPE.When pressed on whether mistakes were made, Mr Hancock said policies had been changed as the Government learnt more about the virus.He said: There are things that weve changed as weve gone through... because weve learned more things about the virus and because things didnt work out as expected.But Intisar was unimpressed with Mr Hancocks answered and pushed him for an apology.He told Mr Hancock: The public is not expecting the Government to handle this perfectly, were not expecting perfection, were expecting progression, were expecting you to admit that mistakes were made, especially to me and people who have really lost loved ones to the virus.Openly acknowledging your mistake is not an admission of guilt, it makes you seem more human. So can you please just do that for me today Mr Hancock ignored Intisars pleas for an apology, telling him: I think that it is very important that we are constantly learning how to do these things title: uk lockdown coronavirus end who
story: Prof Karol Sikora, a leading cancer specialist, warned that thousands more people would die of the disease and heart problemsthe country was kept locked up.He is urging ministers to allow small businesses, shops and garden centres to open first, thereported.He said: As long as we dont see a second wave of the virus then we should plan for full operation by the end of May, including opening schools and even bars and pubs with social distancing.Prof Sikora added: I would be aggressive about it. If we dont do that more people will die from cancer and heart disease.He had previously said some restrictions may be able to be lted this week.He told BBC News this morning: Weve got to get going again to avoid a catastrophe in a year or twos time.But his optimism is countered by more cautious Government scientists, who think that the country must be careful about reopening again.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said yesterday the NHS would start opening up to non-Covid- patients again, with routine operations and cancer treatments restarting.And he urged anyone who needed help to come forwards and stressed: The NHS is open.Gardening shops and recycling centres could be among the first places to re-open, as long as strict social distancing measures stayed in place, it was reported today.Thealso claimed that the Department for Transport were looking at recommending masks for everyone using public transport to stop the spread of the bug any further.As The Sun reported last week, title: rubbish tips set to reopen this weekend
story: Tips and recycling centres will be told they can and should be open as long as safe social distancing remains in place.The move was confirmed today in Parliament by Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick.He said: Our bin men and women have done a fantastic job maintaining the vast majority of collections.The Government published advice to councils on how to ensure the safety of refuse collections on th of April.And today I am announcing that I am asking councils to plan the organised reopening of household waste collection sites.I expect this to happen over the coming weeks and we will publish updated guidance shortly.As more people stay home, officials are said to be concerned at the amount of waste piling up.And some councils have reported a rise in fly tipping as people dump waste on the sides of the roads and outside their homes.Cllr David Renard, Environment spokesman for the Local Government Association said today:  Councils have been able to keep waste services running for communities during the coronavirus crisis.Government social distancing measures and staff absences due to social isolation or sickness have led to household waste and recycling centres closing but councils are keen to open them as soon as practicable.To safely manage visitor flow and pent-up demand, the police will need to manage inevitable traffic queues at the sites, with consideration needing to be given to whether supportive measures, such as a permit system and longer opening hours might be needed.Guernsey announced some easing of its lockdown restrictions but saw huge queues at green waste sites on the island yesterday, with nearly  visitors in a day.They are running at reduced opening hours and subject to even more strict health and safety restrictions.The household waste and recycling centre is due to reopen on Thursday, too, Guernsey Press reported.On Wednesday, it was confirmed local authorities in Rochdale have agreed to reopen some of the  household waste recycling centres across Greater Manchester from Saturday, May .The council said they should only be used by those with a genuine need to dispose of extra waste - and only bagged general waste will be accepted.Some rubbish tips and recycling centres have closed due to the lockdown, but the Government guidance has not specied they must do.Like parks, many local authorities have been making their own decisions on whether to stay open or shut down.And we join The Sun in praising all unsung heroes, including bin crews, for playing their part in keeping the country going.Children across the country, including my three girls, have decorated their bins with colourful pictures to say just that.And we should continue to do this – saying thank you in the brightest way.While it’s important that we show appreciation for what they are doing, we must also make sure they know that we are supporting them.Just last week, coronavirus testing was extended to include bin crews and their households, so that they know they can be tested along with other essential workers.We also know that with more people at home, more rubbish and recycling is being created.This means there’s more to collect.Many councils decided to close their waste and recycling centres during the pandemic, also meaning there is also nowhere to take the extra rubbish.And that’s why I have announced that we are asking councils to reopen these sites as a priority.And we’re supporting them to do this in line with social distancing guidelines, by publishing guidance shortly on how they can operate safely.We all have our part to play – we need to keep up the spirit of unity and beat this challenge together. The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: surge sti cases coronavirus halts clinics cervical screenings
story: CUTBACKS to sexual health services amid the coronavirus pandemic could cause a surge in STI cases in the UK, doctors are warning.STI clinics and cervical screenings have been put on hold across the country due to staff being deployed to other parts of hospitals to help with the Covid- outbreak.However, experts are now warning that the NHS will have to deal with a massive STI problem once the pandemic is over.And they say sexual health services have been “rolled back” by decades amid coronavirus upheaval.Dr Sarah Jarvis, GP and Clinical Director of Patientaccess,told The Sun Online: For men and women who are infected, there is no doubt that services have been reduced.It is easier to get treatment in some parts of the country than others. This could lead to delays which can cause serious health problems, especially for conditions like chlamydia.Tracey Forsyth, lead contraceptive nurse at British Pregnancy Advisory Service, also revealed that women are routinely telling her they are struggling to access sexual health services.She told The Independent: It is very dficult to access contraception, sexual health and have smears at the moment. There were lots of cuts to services before this.We have rolled the clock back with sexual health by decades due to coronavirus and cuts.Ms Forsyth added: Places are worrying we will have a massive STI problem at the end of Covid-.Most people dont experience any symptoms, and dont realise they are infected.Symptoms can include pain or a burning sensation during sex, and an unusual discharge.Women might also experience pain in the lower abdomen during or after sex, and bleeding after sex.In men, chlamydia can also cause a pain or tenderness in the testicles.. HPVHuman papilloma virus , which causes genital warts, is the second most common STI here in Britain.The warts are usually painful, but may be itchy or red. Occasionally, they cause bleeding.HPV is spread by skin-to-skin contact, so you can catch it evenyou havent had penetrative sex - and condoms DONT provide complete protection.. GonorrhoeaGonorrhoea is a bacterial STI - which often has no symptoms.Symptoms include pain or a burning sensation during sex, and an unusual discharge.Less common symptoms in women include pain in the lower gut and bleeding between periods or after sex.In men, gonorrhoea can cause swelling in the foreskin and, in rare cases, pain in the testicles.. HerpesGenital herpes in a common infection caused by HSV virus, which also causes cold sores.The symptoms can develop a few days after contact and include small, painful blisters which itch or tingle - and can make it dficult to urinate.. SyphillisSyphilis is bacterial infection which causes painless - but highly infectious - sores on the genitals and around the mouth.Symptoms for the second stage of syphilis include a rash, flu-like illness and patchy hair loss - which will last for a few weeks.In the third stage, which occurs after several years, people with syphilis may experience heart problems, paralysis and blindness.Ms Forsyth, whose contraceptive team speaks to around  women a week via the phone, said disruption to STI treatment is a problem for both men and women and was a “timely public health issue”.People who have chlamydia and gonorrhoea, and the people they have had sex with, need to be treated, she added.And Ms Forsyth warned that the cuts to sexual health services could have an even more detrimental effect on womens health - with chlamydia having a longer-term risk of pelvic inflammatory disease, which can cause infertility.On top of this, women are concerned about not being able to get smear tests, which help to pick up early signs of cell changes in the cervix that can turn into cancer.Kate Sanger, the spokesperson for charity Jo’s Cervical Cancer Trust, said the guidance from NHS England is to try to continue providing cervical screenings.But we know in some parts of the country, they have stopped sending out invitations for screenings or postponed them for the foreseeable future, she added.Provision is patchy. While there are some women who will want to go, some won’t be able to go because they are self-isolating.Sexual health charities urged the Government to tackle the rising number of STIs in the UK ahead of the coronavirus outbreak.A report by the Terrence Higgins Trust and British Association for Sexual Health  HIVreleased in February drew attention to the “unacceptably high” STI rates with a diagnosis every  seconds on average.In , there were , new diagnoses of STIs, which is an increase of five per cent from the year before.Despite this, Dr John McSorley, BASHH President, says they have seen a reduction in sexually transmitted infections diagnosed in clinics in the past month during lockdown.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. Cases of syphilis are at levels not seen since World War Two. It is important that the Government fully supports ongoing open access to excellent sexual health services for everyone in the UK as we inch our way back towards normality.A happy healthy and fulfilling sex le is a really important cheap and cheerful way of putting a smile back on everyone’s face as summer approaches.If you think you may have an STI, the most important thing is to get tested and get medical advice quickly so you can start treatment.Doctors say you should call your GP or sexual health clinic - or the NHS says self-test kits for STIs are available online.If youre buying a self-test kit online, its important to be wary of the claims they make, as they may be misleading.Before using one, make sure the kit is sealed, without any damage to the packaging, and is within its expiry date.Check that the instructions for use are clear and easy to follow.You should also make sure it has a CE quality assurance mark - this means that, provided you use it correctly, the kit will work properly and is safe.If you think you need to see a doctor in an emergency, AE departments are still open, and doctors are urging people not to avoid seeking help in an emergency due to coronavirus fears.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. All kinds of things:  teeth, childrens toys, a stash of stolen car radios — you name it.Wet wipes have been the biggest culprit in creating fatbergs, as  per cent contain plastic which causes major blockages.Northumbrian Water found that last year, wet wipes were the cause of nearly two thirds of the , blockages in the sewers.These often occurred in the sewer pipes of households, rather than further down in the system.And Wessex Water has warned people not to flush kitchen roll and wet wipes down the loo.It costs the water company a whopping £ million a year to resolve the , blockages a year.A spokesman told Somerset Live: Our simple message isyou are using these items, please put them in the bin, rather than flushing them.They are designed to stay intact, unlike toilet paper which can break down in the sewers.The problem has been particularly bad in Australia, where waste water spills of up to , litres have been caused by sewage blockages, requiring an expensive clean up.These will cost Aussie customers . million a year.GOT a story  Ring The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or email exclusive@the-sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: mike pence mayo clinic mask visit coronavirus testing
story: The leader of the White House coronavirus task force visited a Mayo Clinic lab in Minnesota as part of the Trump administrations efforts to quickly ramp up testing for the virus.The Mayo Clinic is partnering with the University of Minnesota to boost the states testing capacity,Video footage of Pence noticeably not wearing a mask in compliance with the clinics rules quickly circulated around social media.Since April , Mayo clinic has required all patients and visitors to wear a mask or other face covering as suggested in guidance from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.The Mayo Clinic tweeted, but then deleted a message saying they informed the vice president on their mask policy prior to his visit.Social media users slammed the vice president for not wearing a mask and criticized Mayo Clinic for not enforcing their face covering policy.Mayo clinic told Pence to wear mask during visit. He ignored the request. Do as I say, not as I do  said Jim Truswell.Mayo Clinic. You should have refused him entry. He may be the VP...but hes not above God or above hospital rules, said Steve Adams.Who in the world do you think you ARE @Mike_Pence  Im a doctor and I find it disrespectful to the staff and patients you just exposed, wrote Merry De Leon.Former presidential candidate and Hawaii Rep. Tulsi Gabbard also slammed Pence, saying he thumbed his nose at the clinics mask policy.They should have denied him entrance, and not kowtowed to his arrogance, she tweeted Tuesday. Following the wave of backlash, Pence avoided directly answering the question of why he didnt wear a mask and instead cited regular testing of himself and those around him to defend his actions.The vice president has frequently ignored his own task forces guidelines on wearing a facial covering in public.Pence notably wasnt wearing a mask when greeting Colorado Gov. title: contact tracing program ease lockdown coronavirus
story: ALL hail the computer wizards. We’ve known for months that a widespread contact-tracing program is the key to easing draconian lockdown measures safely.And thanks to a swanky new app, such a weapon could be rolled out across the UK in as little as three weeks’ time.Now politicians and the public must pull together to make it a success.The efficacy of contact-tracing hinges on the existence of widely accessible, free testing — so it is welcome news that Health Secretary Matt Hancock has ramped up testing this week.But his government colleagues must explain in detail exactly how our privacy is to be protected, or risk the app going down like a lead balloon with the liberty-loving British public.After that, the ball is in our court.For the program to work, million Brits — that’s  per cent of the population — will need to download the technology and use it properly.Let’s hope and pray we are up to the challenge.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal. LOCKDOWN spring cleaners: your moment has come.After holding out for weeks, ministers have bowed to pressure and permitted councils to reopen rubbish tips. Now, the country’s , garden centres should be allowed to follow suit.We know plants aren’t essential in the strictest sense of the word. But six gruelling weeks of lockdown have left us crying out for physical activities which lt the spirits.Gardening ticks that box admirably. And even for those without the luxury of outdoor space, flowers in a window box may ease lockdown blues a little.Yes, there are risks attached to lting any restriction.But social-distancing in outdoor centres is relatively easy, so let’s get our green fingers back — it’s about blooming time.BORIS Johnson’shas put the wind in the Government’s sails.Testing numbers are rising, businesses are accessing cash, and we are seeing the vague outline of an exit strategy.But still the PPE crisis rages.We have no doubt that getting clothing manufactured and delivered is a logistical nightmare.But there have been repeated stories of manufacturers approaching the Cabinet Office to offer their services in manufacturing PPE only to be drowned in bureaucracy or not answered at all.That is not good enough.Nor is our reliance on deliveries from abroad, which never seem to make it on time.This country has already lost  key workers in the line of duty. title: britain stockpile masks shopping public transport
story: THE UK will build a stockpile of face masks for Brits to wear while shopping and using public transport, it was announced yesterday.It follows weeks of debate and speculation other whether members of the public will be asked to wear face coverings.Cabinet Office minister Michael Gove announced the move after Scottish First Minister Nicola Sturgeon recommended that people use scarves and t-shirts to cover up.Breaking ranks with the Governments official line on masks, she yesterday said the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieshad concluded a face covering would probably help to slow the spread of the virus in confined spaces, like on trains.Ministers are expected to announce their official decision on the matter within days.It comes after The Sun last week revealed the Government was prepared to urge Brits to wear masks to avoid spreading the virus.Our story highlighted how ministers are likely to tell the nation to use something as simple as a scarf when at work, in shops or on public transport.The Government’s top scientists met last week to decide on the face-covering move to help stop the coronavirus spread, amid fears that social distancing will roll into  and chances of a vaccine within a year are slim.And yesterday, Mr Gove said a domestic effort has been launched to slow the spread of coronavirus after he was challenged by Labours Rachel Reeves to build a stockpile for the public.Such masks will be used to limit the droplets that each of us might be responsible for, he said.He told the House of Commons the coverings wont be high-spec surgical face masks required by frontline workers.A No spokesman said: “The NHS is doing a fantastic job and the nation will want to find a way to say thank you when we have defeated this virus.” SAS hero Andy McNab added: “The award of a George Cross would show an emotional appreciation.”We are asking our readers to please sign the petition below.Thereports that Whitehall insiders had wanted to delay the announcement over its guidance for England until enough masks have been stockpiled.And Health Secretary Matt Hancock has insisted face coverings only offer weak protection at best.But Ms Sturgeon said the main benefit of cloth coverings isnt to protect the wearer, but instead to prevent asymptomatic carriers who dont yet realise they have the virus from transmitting it.Mr Hancock told last nights Downing Street press briefing that the most important thing is to continue with social distancing.He was backed by deputy chief scientic adviser Dame Angela McLean, who said there is weak evidence of a small effect of masks preventing carriers from passing on the virus.The chairman of the Royal College of General Practitioners, Professor Martin Marshall, said: Ifare coughing and spluttering then it makes complete sense to wear masks in order to protect other people.He told the BBCs Today programme: I think the guidance that were expecting to hear is that the wearing of face masks is a voluntary activity, not mandated, and it certainly makes a lot of sense to focus limited resources that we have at the moment on those who have greatest need and thats the health professionals.There has been broad disagreement about the potential benefits - last week, chief scientic adviser Sir Patrick Vallance said the evidence on face masks has always been quite iable, quite weak and dficult to know.Yesterday, Chris Hopson, chief executive of the hospitals group NHS providers, told The Times he fears members of the public will rush to buy medical-grade masks, which are much needed by frontline medics.He said: There is bound to be a question in some peoples minds about what form of face covering provides the greatest protection.The scientic evidence is clear - the fluid repellent surgical masks worn by healthcare workers offer greater protection because of the signicantly smaller pore sizes in the material they use.It therefore seems likely that some people will try to purchase these masks.This is why its vital that the threat to this supply is carefully assessed before the government makes decisions.Coronavirus deaths have jumped to more than , in hospitals after  more people died.Positive cases have also risen by , to , as Britain grapples with week six of drastic lockdown measures.But it is understood that when deaths outside hospitals are counted, the true title: ve day 2020 victory bank holiday
story: On May  , victory in Europe was announced, but what exactly is VE Day and how is it celebrated today VE Day stands for Victory in Europe Day which took place on Tuesday, May , .It was the day on which allied forces announced the surrender of Germany in Europe.It marked the end of Adolf Hitler’s war and sparked celebrations around the world.The day before at .pm on May , , Germany had surrendered.Hitler had committed suicide a week earlier leaving Grand Admiral Donitz of the German army to admit defeat.The Normandy landings in June  had proved instrumental in achieving victory for the allies, as had the huge eastern offensives of the USSR.Six years of war that had cost the lives of millions had finally come to a close.In , VE Day falls on a Friday.The May Day bank holiday has been moved this year from May  to May  to mark  years since Nazi Germany surrendered.Before the outbreak of coronavirus, more than , pubs were going to encourage Brits to raise a glass to the fallen heroes.But with lockdown restrictions, all public VE day events have now been cancelled.The May Day bank holiday has only been moved once before, when it was shted from May  to May  to mark  years since VE Day.A crowd of , was packed into Piccadilly Circus waving flags.A national holiday was declared and there was dancing in the street and singing.At pm Prime Minister Winston Churchill broadcast from the War Cabinet Office to tell the nation war was over.It was the same room Neville Chamberlain had announced that the country was at war in .King George VI also spoke to the nation on the radio, paying tribute to those who “laid down their lives” during the war.The Royal Family made eight appearances during the day, waving to crowds on the balcony at Buckingham Palace.The two young princesses - Elizabeth and Margaret – even slipped out of the palace to join the crowds.Some had started the celebrations early and didn’t wait for the official celebrations on May .For those who had lost loved ones it was a bittersweet day and many widows did not take part in the jubilations.In America the day was dedicated to President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who had recently died.President Roosevelt remains the longest-serving president in US history, holding office from  to  and winning an unprecedented four elections.In France huge crowds went to Paris to celebrate.Times were still tough and rationing didn’t officially end until .British and Commonwealth Armed Forces were still fighting in Burma, Singapore and Thailand.It was not until August that Japan surrendered after the US dropped the first two atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.The Second World War came to an end six years and one day after it started on September , , when official surrender documents were signed on the deck of the USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay by the Japanese.The momentous day is still celebrated and remembered by people around Britain each year.The th anniversary of VE Day was marked with a series of events across the UK in .This year the Queen will commemorate the th anniversary with a televised address to the nation.It will be broadcasted on the BBC at . - the exact moment her dad, King George VI gave a radio address  years ago.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA world free from coronavirus could be up to a decade away unless the international community acts on vaccinating the most vulnerable societies, according to former foreign secretary David Miliband.Speaking to the BBC’s Coronavirus Newscast, Mr Miliband, who is now president and CEO of the International Rescue Committee, said he feared that it could be “five or ten years before the people his organisation helps get any snf of a vaccine”. It comes as scientists claim coronavirus is unlikely to be eradicated and mayeach year like seasonal flu.The Chinese expertsapos predictions echo what the UKaposs chief medical officer, professor Chris Whitty chillingly warned last week. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE. Professor Whitty said the country is unlikely toto normal, until a vaccine can be found, as it has for the flu. The Chinese viral and medical researchers told reporters in Beijing that the virus is not likely to disappear like SARS, because it can infect carriers who have no idea they have symptoms and are passing on silently to others. They said Chinese health officials are still confirming dozens of asymptomatic carriers every day. Mr Miliband praised the UK Government for its attempt to start an international discussion on vaccination, but said “the main donor countries to the global aid effort have been pretty myopic about the crisis at the moment”.  The IRC works with survivors of conflict and disaster in  countries. Mr Miliband also warned that while the coronavirus “tsunami” had yet to hit many of the countries where his organisation worked, it could become “rampant” before too long. IRC research based on modelling from Imperial College London and the World Health Organisation estimates that between  million and one billion people will become infected, and between .m and  million people could die.The underlying health vulnerabilities mean that this is going to hit and it’s not going to be stopped until it’s gone really widespread, the former Labour politician continued. We’ve got maybe four weeks to do vital preventative work. Commenting on the Scottish Government’s decision to recommend the wearing of facemasks in enclosed public spaces where social distancing was dficult, Mr Miliband said “it must be a good thing”. “To the extent that it helps at all it must be a good thing. Andyou’ve been to Japan in the last ten years, it’s the norm, he said. So I think it’s going to become the norm. Asked about the UK Government’s response to the pandemic so far, Mr Miliband said he was “worried”. “I’m worried about the testing. I’m obviously relived at the way the NHS has pulled through and people have pulled together. “And Iaposm worried that thereaposs almost a feeling that the debate about the lockdown is an on-off switch and it isnapost.” Mr Miliband added that he felt there was no going back to the way things were. “Thereaposs no going back to the old normal. Thereaposs going to be a new normal, and that trust between the government and people is so important to making this work.” Mr Miliband also told the Coronavirus Newscast that his family had a run-in with their new neighbours.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailTaking waste to your local rubbish tip is essential travel, a senior government minister declared today. George Eustice said people should not be penalised for bringing waste to a dump or recycling centre - which the government has told to reopen in the coming weeks. Government guidance says people should only leave the house for four reasons - shopping for basic necessities, one form of exercise a day, a medical need, or travelling for work purposes. Going to a tip or recycling centre does not feature either in the list of exemptions in the law, or a guide on essential travel from the College of Policing. But ministers are worried fly-tipping has soared, with the Countryside Alliance warning it has risen % in some areas. The Environment Secretary told LBC: We think that it would be essential travel to dispose of waste. We’ve had a problem with fly-tipping because local authorities in some cases took the decision to close those recycling centres. Calling for tips to reopen he added: We think they are a necessary service. We claried guidance on that now in case there was any doubt about that. Many household waste recycling centres closed after government guidance on April  said they only had to stay openpossible. The guidance on prioritising which services to keep open said they were of medium importance. It added: If it is possible to keep HWRCs open, make sure that social distancing rules can be maintained. Always provide adequate staffing levels for health and safety and security purposes. But Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said yesterday the guidance would be amended. He told MPs councils should draw up a plan to reopen in the coming weeks. He added: Public Health England has published guidance for those working in the sector, recommending that where the  metre distance rule cannot be adhered to, staff should make sure that the windows of their vehicles are open for ventilation, and they should wash their hands for  seconds or longer before getting in and out of the vehicle, or use hand sanitiser where handwashing is not possible. We will ensure that councils follow up and adhere to that advice so that those key workers are properly protected as they go about their work.

But in a graphic newly produced for today’s daily coronavirus briefing, the wording had been changed. Who is eligible for a test  As the UK extends its testing capacity a growing list of people are eligible to be tested:All those working on the frontline in health and social carePatients in the NHS and residents in care homesAll other aposessentialapos workers- see full list below Anyone over Anyone who goes into work because they cannot work from home, for example construction workersAnyone who has symptoms and lives with someone who meets any of the above criteriaIn the UK there are around million people classed as essential workers but their households will also be eligible under the scheme. But who is essential  It it the same list of occupations used by the government to determine whether or not you can continue to send your children to school during lockdown. Key workers on the list are the same as those for access to schools, and include NHS and social care workers, police officers, teachers, social workers, those in the justice system, undertakers, some in local government, supermarket and food production workers, journalists, transport workers and some people in utilities and IT. A full list is below or on this web page. How sick do you have to be   You need to show symptoms in order to be tested, unless you work in a care home of for the NHS. The main two are a new and persistent dry cough and a temperature. But other people who have tested positive for covid- include losing taste and a sense of smell.    It will showyou currently have Covid-. This is useful to proveyour symptoms are actually the virus. It does not showyouaposve had Covid- in the past. It will help people work out when they and their household members canto work safely. Where do I log on to book a test  Visit the governmentaposs web page. Slots for testing tend to appear at am and can be snapped up quickly. Where do I go to get tested     The first port of call is a drive-through testing centre - with  promised by the end of April. The government expects you to be able to drive for up to  minutes from your home to get to a drive-through site, leaving some with potentially a -minute round trip. WhatI canapost drive   For those who donapost live near enough to a testing site or canapost drive there are other options. What about other ways of getting tested  Meanwhile apossatelliteapos test kits are also being sent directly to care homes to enable residents with symptoms to be tested. And the Army is helping set up mobile testing units which will travel the country to places like care homes, police stations and prisons. Whataposs it like getting the test   The test involves taking a swab  of the nose and throat - and it goes back pretty far, so be prepared. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has now been under lockdown for more than a month - and thereaposs no sign it will stop soon. But with other European countries beginning to relax their rules, calls are growing for the government to spell out how it will eventually be relaxed. Tory MPs have piled on pressure to save the economy - while Scotland and Wales have tightened the screws by pushing ahead and saying what will happen next. For all the argument and debate, we still donapost have a date when lockdown will be relaxed. And we know it wonapost actually end - it will just be eased bit by bit. But we have ious clues and leaked details which point to how that might happen. Weaposll relax lockdown once the infection rate is low enough, and then use a test, trace, track strategy with an NHS app to keep it low. Hereaposs everything we know about how lockdown will be relaxed, but why we must also get used to a aposnew normalapos that looks dferent to the UK we knew before.How long is the UKaposs coronavirus lockdown  The lockdown expires on May  - six weeks after it began. But thataposs just the legal date it has to be reviewed by. Emergency lockdown powers in the Health Protection Regulations  must be formally reviewed every three weeks. In reality the government will renew the lockdown for longer, at least partly. The question is how much of it will be extended, and for how long.  When will the UK lockdown end - and how  The UK lockdown will start to be relaxed once five tests are met:The NHS is able to cope A sustained fall in deaths New infections dropping enough Adequate testing and PPE No risk of a second peakBut once it is eased it wonapost all happen in one go. Instead the lockdown is set to be relaxed in phases while some social distancing measures stay in place. So while the strictest restrictions should start to ease this summer, some measures look set to be in place until next year. Stand-in PM Dominic Raab adds we might see restrictions tighten in some ways and loosen in others. How will the government decide itaposs time to relax the lockdown  The UK government will have to fulfil all five testson ending the lockdown. Downing Street adds the key test will be how far and fast the infection rate drops. aposRapos - the number of people each carrier infects - is already below , which stops Covid- spreading exponentially. But Health Secretary Matt Hancock has warned it wouldn’t take much to lose that grip. Any change to the restrictions must not risk the aposRapos number going above .So how will we know when thataposs happened  The key piece of evidence will be a study by the Office for National Statistics on the infection rate - expected to be published in early May. That could be crucial in deciding what the government does next. Despite pleas from Tory MPs, Downing Street insists the decision will be based on science before the economy. Boris Johnsonaposs spokesman said: We will have to take decisions based on the best available scientic and health advice. it’s not going to be a case of choosing between the economy and public health.”Will lockdown be relaxed before May   Government sources said there would likely be more details spelt out before May . So the plan is to stop that happening with a three pronged strategy - test, trace and track. None of you would be able to go outside your aposbubbleapos.  Will people have to wear face masks  Itaposs not clear yet. Ministers are considering how to act on advice from the governmentaposs scientic advisors SAGE. The group decided there is weak evidence of a small effect in which a face mask can prevent someone whoaposs already infected, infecting those around them. Scotland has advised its residents to wear face coverings, either a mask or improvised facial shield such as a scarf, in limited circumstances in public when they have to be in close quarters with others. This is not mandatory. Why have Scotland and Wales got dferent plans - and what does it mean  Deep splits have opened up in the strategy across the UK. Wales and Scotland are both pushing ahead with telling the public what post-lockdown might look like, but the UK government refuses to say. So far, the actual plans remain pretty similar in each country - in fact, Matt Hancock has said Scotlandaposs plan is pretty similar to what heaposs been looking at. Itaposs just the communication with the public that has been split. But that risks changing as Wales and Scotlandaposs chiefs - who sit on crucial COBRA meetings about the lockdown - pile pressure on Boris Johnson and have powers over places like schools and care homes. The split forced the Health Secretary to plead for unity, saying: So far we have moved as one United Kingdom and I think that has been a very good thing. My preference is that we work together as one country. A Downing Street spokesman warned the nations: I’m sure they like us will be guided by the science - and won’t want to do anything that could risk a second peak”. Whataposs happening in Scotland  Scotlandaposs First Minister set out a -page blueprint for easing the lockdown. Nicola Sturgeon said businesses might be able to reopenthey can keep customers and staff  metres apart. The same would have to be in place in schools with modications needed in some classrooms. But pubs and mass gatherings would likely have to remain closed for longer. Despite spelling out an exit strategy, Ms Sturgeon warned normal as we knew it is not on the cards in the near future. Nicola Sturgeon said lting the lockdown is not a flick of the switch moment but more of a gradual change to the current conditions. No insisted Scotlandaposs plan was actually pretty similar to its own in terms of what needs to happen before lockdown ends.  Whataposs happening in Wales  Walesapos First Minister Mark Drakeford said lockdown could be left in three phases, like a traffic light in reverse. The red phase would see only the most careful and controlled lting of restrictions, amber would see more restrictions lted andthe virus does not re-emerge, Wales could move to the green zone. But he believed that UK ministers were nervous about entering into a similar conversation with the public for fear it would undermine the message to stay at home. The Welsh Government will also need seven questions to be answered before easing the lockdown. They are:Would easing a restriction have a negative effect on containing the virus  Does a particular measure pose a low risk of further infection  How can it be monitored and enforced  Can it be reversed quicklyit creates unintended consequences  Does it have a positive economic benefit  Does it have a positive impact on people’s wellbeing  Does it have a positive impact on equality

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAnxiety symptoms can often be very similar to those of coronavirus, doctors warn. With the death toll of those with Covid- on the sharp rise again in the UK today, doctors say it is unsurprisingwe feel particularly anxious at the moment.But some symptoms of anxiety are physical ones, unlike psychological symptoms which largely affect our mind. Tightness in the chest and shortness of breath are telltale signs of anxiety - but can also be symptoms of coronavirus. Dr Sarah Jarvis, clinical director of Patientaccess, said: Some of the symptoms of anxiety and panic attacks – feeling short of breath, palpitations, dizziness etc – are sometimes also seen in coronavirus. The doctor, though, suggested ways to tell that itaposs definitely anxiety and not coronavirus. . Shortness of breath Dr Jarvis said people take a few minutes to check in with themselves and try to steady their breathing. The symptoms of panic attacks tend to settleyou concentrate on your breathing and take very slow breaths, she added. Try tummy breathing - put one hand on your chest and the other on your tummy. You should aim to breathe quietly by moving your tummy with your chest moving very little. If you were able to calm yourself down and find a steady breathing pattern within those few minutes, you may not be dealing with coronavirus. But the World Health Organisationsaysyou have coronavirus your chest may begin to feel tight or you begin to feel as though you cannot breathe deeply enough to get a good breath. Shortness of breath associated with the Covid- infection is progressive in nature and can become le-threatening over a period of hours to days without medical care. - - - - - - - - ,- - ,+ - ,  . Problems with digestion Stomach pains, constipation and diarrhoea are signs of anxiety, doctors say. This is largely because the communication system between your brain and the enteric nervous system, which governs your digestion, is affected by stress. Of course, eating foods that don’t agree with you or not exercising can affect your digestion too. However, researchers recently studied data from  patients with Covid- in China’s Hubei province and discovered that . per cent of these patients arrived at the hospital with digestive symptoms such as diarrhoea, vomiting or abdominal pain. These symptoms, though, were usually accompanied by more typical signs such as a dry cough and high temperature. Therefore,you are only experiencing digestive issues it is unlikely to be coronavirus.  . Increased heart rate An increased heart rate is a classic sign of anxiety, according to the National Institute of Mental Health . Adrenal glands churn out hormones when you are faced when something stressful. So, receptors in your heart react by speeding up your heartbeat as a result. This lets you to pump more blood to your big muscles so you could theoretically flee or combat a threat. However, a racing heart rate can also signal coronavirus, doctors suggest. Dr As Munaf, an NHS consultant, said an elevated heart and breathing rates could indicate “you’ve potentially got signs of an infection, which in this climate could be Covid-”. If itaposs an anxiety attack, your heart rate should settleyou concentrate on your breathing and take very slow breaths. However,itaposs coronavirus your heart rate is likely to remain fast - especially during any form of exercise or movement.  . Muscle pain Your muscles tense up as part of your stress responseyou are suffering from anxiety. Many people with anxiety report feeling tight in their neck, back, or shoulders. But, likewise, some coronavirus patients report muscle soreness across their body. According to WHO, about  per cent of all Covid- patients experienced body aches or joint pain. These aches are triggered by chemicals called cytokines - which the body releases while responding to the infection. Muscle pains in coronavirus patients, though, are usually accompanied by other more well-known symptoms. If you are worried about your symptoms, you can ring  for the NHSapos dedicated service. To protect others, do not go to places like a GP surgery, pharmacy or hospital.

Jamie Hunter and partner Beccy Flint found out they were expecting their first child together last year with a due date of the end of May . But in October last year teacher Jamie started to suffer a crippling pain in his side.After lots of tests and scans he was finally diagnosed with kidney cancer in March, reports Birmingham Live. Last month the -year-old was told the cancer had spread to his liver and there was no cure. The brave couple, from Sutton Coldfield, have made the decision to deliver their baby on May  in the hope Jamie can have the chance to meet and cuddle his newborn. Best friend Phil Taylor said: Jamie will never be able to celebrate his baby’s first birthday, teach them to ride a bike and learn to swim or be there for their first day at school. These are the things we take for granted.  Asle isn’t cruel enough, Beccy may have to face childbirth without Jamie, as his health is deteriorating every day. Phil, who met Jamie  years ago, and friend Chad Duggan have launched a crowdfunding page in a bid to raise £, to support Jamieaposs care, his family and Baby Hunter. There has been a huge response to the appeal and it has been retweeted by Aston Villa captain Jack Grealish. They were over the moon about having a baby, it was everything heaposs wanted, said Phil, who is a plumber. Heaposs always put himself out for everyone  before himself.  He has managed two under-sevens teams right through to under-s and onto adult teams. Jamie is also a huge Manchester United fan with a massive heart, who has dedicated his le to football and teaching.He added: Heaposs godfather to my daughter and my best friend. I know the money we raise isnapost going to keep him here. If it could, Iaposd give it all back. But I thought we should do whatever we can to support Beccy and the baby. Jamie, who works as a PE teacher at John Wilmott School in Sutton Coldfield, joined Sutton United as a teenager and ed as a manager and coach after deciding to stop playing in .  Phil said: He has taken teams from six and seven years of age all the way through to adult football. Jamie loved this so much he did it twice! He added: As a PE teacher, he has touched so many lives and has been an outstanding role model, developing young people through all walks of le. The kids love him at school, heaposs always helping kids. Alongside his amazing coaching efforts he also played for the clubaposs first team. The friends hope to raise £, for Jamie and his family and have pledged a donation would be made to John Taylor Hospice,which has been supporting the couple, who met through football.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA dental professor has urged people to brush their teeth before leaving the house in a bid to prevent the spread of coronavirus. Martin Addy, emeritus professor of dentistry at the University of Bristol, said toothpaste can reduce the chances of catching or spreading the disease through the mouth. However, he warned that the antimicrobial effect of toothpaste only lasts from three to five hours. He therefore suggested Brits brush their teeth before going outside to ensure the effect is active should they come into contact with other people. In a letter in yesterdayaposs Times, Mr Addy, wrote: Scientists, in support of mouth and nasal coverings, have emphasised the role of saliva droplets in the spread of Covid-. Follow our live blog for the latest updates about coronavirus It is perhaps surprising, therefore, that toothbrushing with toothpaste has not been emphasised as an effective procedure.Toothpaste contains the same detergents as those found in handwash gels recommended against coronavirus.Indeed, the antimicrobial action of toothpaste in the mouth persists for three to five hours and, thereby, would reduce the viral load in saliva or infection by viruses entering the mouth. Mr Addy said people wanting to maximise the preventative effects could brush their teeth just before leaving the house. He added: As a large proportion of our population is in lockdown, one of the brushings could be immediately before leaving home for exercise, shopping etc. For those workers in the NHS, brushing should be before putting on protective equipment.

story: NewsMischievous toddler shaves huge patch off her hair using dog clippersSariah Coombs, from Hawarden, north Wales, wandering around her home with clumps of long, blonde locks falling from her head after her mischiefShareCommentsByBradley JollyDigital journalistTfany Wallis:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsSariah Coombs, two, ran away with the familys dog clippers" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A cheeky toddler shaved off a huge patch of her hair with dog clippers when her mum thought she was just watching TV.Little Sariah Coombs, two, snuck off with the clippers when mum Sian, , had her back turned and contrived to hack her locks. And minutes later, Sian found her daughter wandering around their home in Hawarden, north Wales, with clumps of long, blonde locks falling from her head. My daughter is absolutely doggy obsessed and she loves to help me but the dogs didn’t enjoy her brushing them so I gave her a bowl of treats to feed to the dogs to distract them while I brushed, Mrs Coombs said today. She was doing a great job and by feeding the treats to the puppies, she kept them distracted and it kept her entertained too - so all was going well. I just assumed she’d gone to join her other siblings watching TV or something. But she ed moments later holding the dog clippers in her hand, and as soon as I spotted her holding them, I leapt to get them off her but then noticed what she had done. Mrs Coombs , who is also mum to Thomas , Amara , Henry seven, and five-year-old Percy, panicked as she realised Sariah managed to shave a whole patch down the middle of her head.  She said: The hair was still sort of stuck to her head, but as I began touching it, clumps came away in my hand and I could see what had happened. Sariah’s first reaction was to say mummy did it as Sian was left standing with clumps of her daughter’s hair in her hands. Despite her initial reaction being gobsmacked, Sian said in hindsight she is relieved her toddler didnapost take the clippers to one of the dogs as they have a litter of seven-week-old puppies in the house.  She said: My first instinct was of course one of horror, but I saw the big smile on her face change into an anxious expression when she saw my face so I quickly realised I needed to hide my own feelings to protect her. She’s still breastfed so immediately upon realising there was a problem she asked for ‘bobos’ so I just fed her to calm her down, and give me time to gather my thoughts a little. I didn’t show her the result of her hair until a little while later but she just laughed when she saw herself in the mirror which I was relieved about.  Describing her little one as absolutely full of le, Sian said her cheeky little girl is into everything at the moment. She said: She copies me with every task I do and she’s very bright. I don’t think there’s much in my house that she doesn’t know where it belongs or how it works. She notices everything and just loves to join in and help out. Just days earlier, Mrs Coombs said she had spotted Sariah checking all of the puppies with a stethoscope - so she is glad she didn’t decide to give them all a haircut. The mother said it was also heartwarming to see how none of the other children seemed to mind about their youngest sibling’s new hair-do.  Mrs Coombs added: My children didn’t say much to be honest. They don’t really care what her hair is like, they just love her for who she is regardless of anything . They all immediately went out onto the trampoline and played together like nothing had happened. My eldest was probably the most shocked, my teenage daughter just thought it was funny and the younger boys have barely mentioned it. However, Mrs Coombs admitted that her husband, Paul, did questionshe was joking when she messaged him to tell him the news. She said: He feels the same as me. We just love her to bits and want her to be happy, nothing  matters. These things happen in le sometimes.  Sian said she considered shaving off the rest of Sariah’s hair, but has decided to leave it after reaching out for some advice. She added: I messaged my hairdresser and a few hairdresser friends who all told me to leave it be. I also asked Sariah and she got upset at the thought of having the rest shaved. My only concern now is to protect her feelings. She doesn’t want it cutting so I won’t. I just want her to feel happy and not worry about it so we’re not making an issue of it.

story: NewsSurprising new measles-like symptoms affecting children with coronavirusDoctors around the world are urgently investigating the concerning reports of inflammatory symptoms similar to Kawasaki disease affecting children in countries with severe Covid- outbreaks, including the UKShareCommentsByTom DavidsonSenior Reporter:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsOne of the symptoms of Kawasaki disease is a rash on the hands and feet" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Concerned parents have described aposmeasles-likeapos symptoms their children have suffered while fighting suspected coronavirus.There have been numerous reports of children fighting covid- experiencing rashes and other inflammatory ailments, in the UK and abroad. Although not confirmed in all cases, the symptoms are similar to Kawasaki disease, of which there has been an increase in cases in countries dealing with bad Covid- outbreaks. On Monday, doctors were issued an alert about a sharp rise of infants being admitted to intensive care with a Kawasaki-like disease in Britain and Italy. The illness is generally more common in parts of Asia. Kawasaki disease primarily affects children under five years of age, with symptoms including a rash swollen glands in the neck dry, cracked lips red fingers or toes and red eyes. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said on Monday he was aposvery worriedapos about reports of the inflammatory condition, as top doctor Prof Chris Whitty said itaposs plausible it was being triggered by Covid-.Have you been affected by this story  Email webnews@mirrorSimilar cases have been reported in the USA and it has left doctors and medical professionals there baffled. Right now, weaposre at the very beginning of trying to understand what that represents, Columbiaaposs Dr Mark Gorelik told Reuters. Dr Gorelik said he believes the cases are likely not Kawasaki disease, but a similar process that shares an underlying mechanism with Kawasaki, which is thought to be triggered by an infectious agent that sparks an immune response. The three New York cases follow a report at Stanford University in Calornia, in which a -month-old was admitted to the hospital with Kawasaki disease and was later diagnosed with Covid-. TODDLER SUFFERING WITH KAWASAKI AFTER FEVER Gemma Brownaposs two-year-old son is suspected of having the aposinflammatory syndromeapos linked to Covid-, the Mail reports. Doctors were initially baffled by the boyaposs symptoms after the tot developed a fever and rash across his body. But a senior consultant eventually diagnosed the boy with the rare Kawasaki disease, a form of toxic shock syndrome which causes the body’s immune system to attack its own organs. Gemma told Mail Online: I asked for him to be tested, as I had a gut feeling that there was a connection between COVID- and Kawasaki. Both attack your immune system and the whole family had been poorly with Covid symptoms before he fell ill. I was adamant that there was a link and was begging for a test, but they just told me that there was no need to test the under-fives. The brave lad was given an immunoglobin transfusion and was in hospital for five days. TEEN CRITICAL WITH CORONAVIRUS HAD aposMEASLES LIKEapos RASH    Lewis Greig suffered a measles-like rash, red swollen eyes and vomiting before being admitted to hospital and testing positive for coronavirus. The -year-old remains on a ventilator to help him breathe, and is described as critical but stable. His mum Karen Simpson, , said: He started being sick, had a sore head and was really tired. “By Thursday, he had developed a measles-like rash on his hands and his eyes went deep red and bloodshot. One of the doctors said to us children don’t present with a dry cough like adults do. In children, there’s an inflammatory reaction which makes it look like an autoimmune disease. Karen is warning other parents to keep an eye out for similar symtoms.

At first she started with a headache and back ache but put it down to work stress. But her condition deteriorated and she was left struggling to breathe. The South Western Ambulance Service medic is now warning people to be on the lookout for less obviousapos symptoms and to heed Government advice to stay indoors. She said: Iaposm a - year-old girl working on the front line as a NHS paramedic. I tested positive for Covid- and wanted to share my experience to warn others who display less aposobviousapos symptoms like I did at first. We are building a map of appreciation for the NHS heroes looking after us through the coronavirus crisis. Place your heart on our live updating map at www.thanksamillionnhs. Add your partial postcodeto put a heart on the map and you can add a thank you message too. If youaposre an NHS worker, youaposll also find a handy list of all the places and brands currently offering you well-deserved discounts. Share the page to encourage others to show their support! She added: I am now well and Iaposm feeling very grateful that I am able to continue to work when so many people are facing real hardship during this crisis - Iaposm one of the lucky ones right now. Kirstine, of Poole, Dorset, has decided to share a diary covering her week-long fight against the deadly bug which has so far claimed more than , lives in the UK. Day One It began with headaches. I developed severe headaches above both eyes, which got worse and worse. The worst headaches Iaposve ever had. Day Two Kirstine began experiencing back aches. I woke up with a headache, but put it down to stress headaches. Given the current situation at work, I didnapost think a headache was very signicant. About mid day I started getting a really achy back. Again, working as a paramedic involves lting people down the stairs. Itaposs not uncommon for me to get an achy back. However that night the pain in my back was so bad I realised that this probably wasnapost my normal aches.Day Three The aches got worse and spread around her body, as she lost her sense of smell. I woke with full body aches still mostly in my back and my head I called in sick, still unsure whether I was doing the right thing as I didnapost have a cough, no temperature. Was it just a bad back and headaches due to the stress weaposre all under  Later that day everything got worse, I didnapost leave bed, and by the evening I had some pains in my chest and felt a little breathless when moving around. I decided to disinfect my surfaces in my bedroom, and thataposs when I realised I couldnapost smell a thing. I proceeded to smell everything around the house, but absolutely nothing! Day Four A mild cough began and Kirstineaposs sense of taste vanished. The aches and pains started to improve. Only today I developed a slight dry cough. The coughing was constant for an hour or two in the morning but then was so spread out Iaposd maybe only have an episode of coughing once every  hours. I realised today that I also couldnapost taste although I probably couldnapost yesterday but I didnapost eat anything to notice.

title: pregnant woman tears shop worker
story: NewsPregnant woman in tears as shop worker says she must queue like everyone Amanda Grant, from Wavertree, Liverpool, and who is due to give birth in just six weeks, visited a branch of The Range in the city on SundayShareCommentsByCharlotte HadfieldBradley JollyDigital journalist:,  APR NewsAmanda Grant, , has been struggling to stand in supermarket queues for long periods of time " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA heavily pregnant mum claims she was left in tears after a shop worker allegedly told her to queue like everyone .Amanda Grant, aged , has been struggling to stand in supermarket queues for long periods of time due to current social distancing rules. The woman, who is due to give birth in six weeks, told Liverpool Echo she has had to queue for over half an hour to get into some stores, which has left her in agony and feeling like Iaposm going to faint.And the single mum-of-three claims she called The Range in Fairfield, Liverpool, on Sunday to find outthere were any allowances being made for pregnant women, doing their essential shopping.Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog hereBut an employee allegedly told her that only NHS staff were allowed to go to the front of the queue and alleges the staff member told her you will have to queue up like everyone . The Range is one of my go to shops because it has an Iceland and I can get all of my essential items under one roof. Iaposm trying to only go out shopping once a week to get food for me and the kids but when I have, Iaposve really struggled to wait outside with no seats and in the blazing sun, Amanda, from Wavertree, Liverpool, said today. The last time I went shopping I thought I was going to faint in the queue, I was queuing up round the car park for half an hour. I was in agony carrying the weight. The global coronavirus pandemic is not just affecting people’s physical health. The anxiety, stress and uncertainty of it – and the sweeping changes we’re having to make to our lestyles – are also having an impact on people’s mental health too. If it’s making you feel that way, then you’re not alone. It’s quite normal to feel this way in such a dficult and unpredictable situation. Here are some tips and strategies recommended by our BACP members to help you cope with the mental health impacts of the current global situation. Keep a routine Many people are working from home for the first time in their lives, and some will now be juggling a full-time job and home-schooling their children. Plus, there are people whose usual activities have been curtailed by self-isolation. Our member Vasia Toxavidi says keeping a routine can be really important. “Without a routine, negative thinking and anxiety can escalate. I would suggest that people create a day to day plan of things they will need to do e.g. create a morning exercise programme, work from homepossible, cook something dferent, get into an online course.” Think about restricting access to news media and social media Many of our members recommend having a think about how and when you access the news or social media. This may involve choosing news sources you trust – and avoiding social media channels filled with speculation. Stick to the official government guidance and NHS advice websites. Or limit your access to the news to a certain time of the day. “Some people can be quite paralysed by this anxiety and may want to completely stop interacting with the news,” says Elizabeth Turp.  Keep connected with friends and family In our new world of self-isolation and social distancing, we can’t meet up with family and friends like we used to. But keeping connected to them is vital. Melani Halacre recommends “connecting online with friends and talking about other stuff, inventing new fun ways to connect. An online pub quiz among friends...learn a dance routine at home then share it  Play games online  Cook the same recipe in your own home whilst online ” Be present Emma Brand recommends ‘being present.’ “Take a breath and really experience where you are and how you are feeling. To take in your surroundings and thank the space environment and people in your space - to actively be grateful is very powerful,” she says. Practise gratitude Hansa Pankhania also recommends being grateful for what you have, instead of what you do not. And Natasha Page recommends keeping a gratitude diary, where you write down three things you are grateful for every day. She adds: These can be small things such as the sun shining, hearing your child laugh, a home-cooked meal, a cosy bed. Think about what are the things you do have and are grateful for. Try some breathing and relaxation techniques Take a five-second breath in through the nose, hold that breath for five seconds and then breathe out for five seconds. Do this five times, says Catherine Gallacher. Melani Halacre recommends the STAR technique. “Smile, take aand relax...breathing out longer than in to override fight and flight mechanism,” she says. Cate Campbell also recommends trying mindfulness or relaxation apps, and practising deep breathing. Write down your anxieties, and let them go It can help to express this anxiety in a way that you can control. That could be writing down what you feel, or keeping a journal. “Acknowledge that you feel this way. Don’t ignore these feelings,” says Elizabeth Turp. “Allow yourself to worry, put it down in writing in a notebook, and then put that away. Let it go.” Get access to natural light Lockdown may have limited your trips to parks and for countryside walks, but itaposs still important to get access to natural light, says Rakhi Chand. Our exposure to natural light is limited at the moment, and this affects our serotonin and melatonin levels - both vital for our mental health. Rakhi recommends sitting near windows and making home environments as light and airy as possible. If youaposre lucky enough to have a a balcony or garden, use it regularly.  She also says that certain foods - such as walnuts, almonds or bananas - can help boost melatonin, and salmon, eggs and spinach are among the foods that can help boost serotonin. She also says itaposs worth looking into Vitamin D supplements, a light therapy lamp and limiting blue light from phones or screens as it disrupts circadian rhythm. Look after your wellbeing Make sure you are looking after yourself, doing what you can to help get a good night’s sleep, eating well and doing exercise, adds Catherine Gallacher. “I always talk to my clients about a wellbeing check. Sleeping, eating, exercising. If we manage our health like this, it can help make us more robust against anxiety.” Running either on the spot, or outside, releases endorphins and fools the brain and body that they’ve run away from the danger, says Cate Campbell. Use all your senses One of the self-care tips recommended by Eve Menezes Cunningham is to use all your senses to notice where you are. You might want to notice five things you can see right now, five things you can hear right now, says Eve, or any smells or tastes. “These can help us resist the well-worn neural pathways around catastrophising and feeling helpless.” There are more of Eve’s self-care tips available to read here. No expectations, no pressure Sarah Wheatley, who specialises in helping new parents, says that she often discusses with her clients, how “when we live in extraordinary times, all bets are off.” “Since expectations can be one of the things that are dficult to manage as a new parent, when there are no expectations it can be really freeing and allow people time to find their way without any pressure. “The pressure to get back into shape, the pressure to socialise, the pressure to feed certain ways, the pressure to feel calm and relaxed, the pressure to look as though you have it ‘all together’. These pressures are reduced by physical isolation, and can be helpful to some mothers.” Positive thinking At times, this may feel very dficult to do depending on your personal situation. But re-framing a negative situation into a positive one can be very helpful. Indira Chima says: “I believe there are a lot of positives to be gained, which might not be apparent right now. It forces people to slow down and breathe and take stock and that is always a good thing.   “We live at such a fast, frenetic pace and sometimes donapost stop to think about what itaposs all about and where we are heading.  This is forcing us to do that.  And we will grow as a result of this.” Ask for support “It’s not a sign of weakness, but strength to reach out and ask for support,” says Hansa Pankhania “Make a list of everyone you know, friends, family, colleagues, neighbours etc. Now tick  people from this list, who can provide practical, psychological and moral support.  Connect with them and sustain this support circle.” If you would like support from a qualied professional, many counsellors offer online or telephone counselling. They can help you explore and understand what youaposre feeling. To find a counsellor or psychotherapist who can help you visit our Therapist Directory. I rang my mum and started crying. I said I donapost even want to go food shopping anymore because I canapost bare standing in these queues for so long. She said theyaposll probably have a policy in place for pregnant woman, so I rang up the Range to ask.The mother said she canapost get family members to do her shopping for her because they are in the high risk category for coronavirus.She continued: I was embarrassed to even phone them up but when I got through I asked the girlthere was a queue and she said yes.  I told her my situation, that Iaposm pregnant and canapost physically queue up for that long but I needed essential items. I askedthey have a policy for pregnant women, so I donapost have to wait in it and her reply really upset me. She said no you will have to queue up just like everyone , we only allow NHS staff to go to the front of the queue. I broke down when I got off the phone. The Range has been approached for comment. Amanda said she also suffers from a condition called SPD, which prevents her from being able to stand for long periods of time and can cause extreme pain.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailScientists believe an anti-viral nasal spray could treat Covid- and stop the infection reaching the lungs, following positive lab tests in Britain.University of St Andrews spin-out company Pneumagen has carried out three separate lab-based studies into preventing coronavirus infections, including Sars-CoV- infection, the cause of Covid-.These have used Neumil and multivalent Carbohydrate Binding Modules , generated using its GlycoTarge technology. Neumil, the companyaposs lead mCBM, is already being developed for the universal treatment of respiratory tract infections , including Influenza Virus , Respiratory Syncytial Virus , and now coronaviruses. For updates on coronavirus, follow our live blog HERE.   Lead researcher Gary Taylor, professor of biology at St Andrews, told the Daily Mail : Classic antivirals actually attack some part of the virusaposs machinery, whereas our drug actually inhibits the virus from even getting into cells. We envision it being given as a nasal spray, and imagine it being given weekly or every other day.  It works by masking glycan receptors in patientsapos airways and thereby preventing the entry of the virus and has the potential to revolutionise the treatment of RTIs. This is because it provides clinicians with the opportunity to offer patients total protection against any circulating viral strain.  The successful studies involved both treating infection and blocking new infections with MCBMs, using plaque - visible structures in a sheet of cells - reduction tests. Pneumagen has been working closely with Public Health Englandaposs Porton facility and separately with the University of GlasgowapossMRC Centre for Virus Research. At both Porton and UoG, the mCBMs were found to reduce the number of Sars-CoV- plaques in these tests when the mCBMs were used in both prevention and treatment of infection. Pneumagen now wants to begin clinical testing for the prevention and treatment of Covid-. Its chief executive Douglas Thomson said: Todayaposs positive results from in-vitro studies of our mCBMs against coronaviruses show that glycan binding has the potential to prevent and treat infection. This further supports the value of our universal therapeutic modality to block access to lung cells of Sars-CoV-, as well as other viruses, that cause respiratory tract infections, providing the potential for a pan-viral respiratory product. Our goal is now to rapidly begin clinical testing for the prevention and treatment of Covid-. A glycan is a generic name for a carbohydrate complex, made up from connected carbohydrate, or sugar, molecules.
